Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI studies a variety of problems in non-holonomic dynamics. The study is related with rigidity theory, the theory of completely integrable systems with continuous and discrete time, contact geometry, and the theory of Hill's equation. The main theme of the research is an interaction between continuous and discrete, and between rigidity and flexibility. The methods of study are mostly geometrical. The project has grown out of the PI's work in these areas in the last several years.

This research project has a potential of making an impact in a number of applied fields including vehicle motion theory, pursuit problems, theoretical robotics, and flotation theory. The developed methods and new insights will find applications in various other problems of contemporary interest, modeled by ordinary differential and finite difference equations. The PI is the Director of the Mathematics Advance Studies Semesters Program (MASS) at Penn State. The project has an additional impact by engaging the MASS participants, advanced undergraduate students from across the USA, and influencing their career choices in mathematics and related disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project concerned a problem in non-holonomic kinematics, a bicycle model. The main emphasis was on the relation between the bicycle kinematics, and applied areas such as flotation theory, vehicle motion theory, pursuit problems, the theory of Hill's equation, rigidity theory, and  the theory of completely integrable systems, continuous and discrete. 

In particular, the so-called bicycle correspondence provides symmetries of the filament (also known as binormal, or local induction, or smoke ring, equation), a hundred years old model for vortex filament dynamics.

The results of this research were published in peer-reviewed journals and reported at national and international conferences and workshops. The principal investigator payed much attention ot dissemination of his results: he lectured at several schools for undergraduate and graduate students, and junior researchers. 

Two graduates students were mentored; both are about to graduate with doctoral degrees in mathematics. Both research assistants were supported by this grant (teaching buyout, summer support, travel).

Topics from the principal investigator's research program were used for summer undergraduate research projects. This research led to several student publications (occasinally, jointly with their supervisors) in peer-reviewed journals and to award-winning presentations at student research conferences.

As an outreach effort, the principal investigator presented topics from his research to high school audiences.
